introduction.p:
Massless particles refer to particle whose rest mass m_0 is zero.
\textrm{Massless particles: } m_0 = 0.
The momentum of a massless particle will be zero unless it has speed equal to the speed of light.
\vec p = \lim_{m_0\rightarrow 0} \dfrac{m_0 \vec v}{\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}} = 0\ \ \ (v \ne c).
When v=c, the denominator becomes zero and momentum becomes undefined. In that case, we use Eq. to find momentum of a massless particle. Thus,
\lim_{m_0\rightarrow 0}\left[ E^2 = p^2 c^2 + m_0^2 c^4 \right]\ \Longrightarrow\ E^2 = p^2 c^2.
Therefore, momentum of a massless particle moving at speed v=c, such as light particle photon, is not zero. Rather, it depends on energy of the particle.
p = \frac{E}{c}.
The energy of each photon depends on the frequency of the light. Each photon of light of frequency f has energy equal to hf, where h is Planck constant, whose value is equal to 6.627\times 10^{-34} J.s.
E = h f.
Therefore, momentum a photon will be related to its frequency as
p = \dfrac{E}{c} = \dfrac{hf}{c}.
Writing the ratio of c to f as the wavelength \lambda of light,
\lambda = \dfrac{c}{f},
we obtain an interesting result relating the momentum and wavelength of light.
p\lambda = h.

exercise.title: Decay of a Neutral Pion in Photons

statement.p: A neutral pion, \pi^{0}, decays into two light particles, called photons. The rest mass of neutral pion is 135\:\textrm{MeV/c}^2. That is, if you multiply 135\:\textrm{MeV/c}^2 by c^2 you will get the rest energy in MeV unit. Find the energy and momenta of the two photons released when a neutral pion at rest decays into two photons.

solution.p:
Let E be the energy of one of the photons. Balancing the energy in the decay reaction we find
2E = 135\:\textrm{MeV}.
Therefore, the energy of each photon is
E \amp = 67.5 \:\textrm{MeV} = 67.5 \:\textrm{MeV} \times 10^6\times 1.67\times 10^{-19}\: \textrm{J/MeV} \amp = 1.13\times10^{-11}\: \textrm{J}.
The momentum of each photon
p = \frac{E}{c} = \frac{1.13\times10^{-11}\: \textrm{J}}{3.0\times 10^8\:\textrm{m/s}} = 3.77\times 10^{-20}\:\textrm{kg.m/s}.
